perturbation.original_text:
1.4 Licensed Patent(s)
The term "Licensed Patent" or "Licensed Patents" means any patent or patents issued at any time in any country (including any inventor's certificates, extension, reissued, renewal and reexamined patents), which (1) is based on any invention made on or prior to the Effective Date, including any patents for inventions disclosed in patent applications filed on or prior to the Effective Date, and issuing from any of those patent applications or any patent applications which are continuations, continuing applications, continuations-in-part or divisions of those patent applications, or on any foreign counterpart of any of those patent applications, (2) (a) is owned by SONY or any of its Affiliates or (b) under which SONY or its Affiliates have the right to grant licenses without payment by SONY or any of its Affiliates of additional royalties or other consideration to a third party (excluding payments for inventions made by that third party while employed by SONY or any of its Affiliates), and (3) would, in the absence of a license granted herein, be infringed by making, using, selling, offering for sale, importing or supplying any Competing Products (including, without limitation, the SRAM Products). "Licensed Patents" shall exclude the Transferred Patents.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.4 Licensed Patent(s)
The term "Licensed Patent" or "Licensed Patents" means any patent or patents issued at any time in any country. "Licensed Patents" shall exclude the Transferred Patents.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Licensed Patents" contained specific criteria related to the invention date, ownership, royalty obligations, and infringement related to Competing Products. By removing these criteria, the modified definition becomes overly broad and conflicts with other sections that rely on a more precise definition. For example, Section 3.1, 'Grant by SONY,' licenses PURCHASER to make Competing Products under the Licensed Patents. Without the original criteria, it's unclear which patents are actually licensed, leading to potential disputes and enforcement uncertainty.

perturbation.original_text:
8.2 Essential Patents
The Transferred Patents listed on Exhibit A comprise the Patents, both U.S. and foreign, owned or claimed by SONY or any SONY Affiliate, that are essential to the conduct of the Business as conducted by SONY.
perturbation.changed_text:
8.2 Essential Patents
The Transferred Patents listed on Exhibit A comprise some Patents, both U.S. and foreign, owned or claimed by SONY or any SONY Affiliate, related to the conduct of the Business as conducted by SONY.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that the listed Transferred Patents are 'essential' to the business. Changing this to 'related to' significantly weakens the claim. This change introduces uncertainty because if the patents are not essential, the value of the assignment is diminished. Furthermore, it could contradict statements in the recitals about SONY's intellectual property being vital to the business, potentially opening SONY up to liability if the purchaser relied on the original representation.

perturbation.original_text:
9.3 Successors and Assigns
This IP Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective successors and permitted assigns, but will not be assignable or delegable by any Party without the prior written consent of the other Party. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Party may transfer or assign its rights under this IP Agreement in connection with a merger, acquisition or sale of all or substantially all of its assets, on condition that it provides the other Party with notice of the transfer or assignment. Any attempted transfer in contravention of this Section 9.3 shall be null and void.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.3 Successors and Assigns
This IP Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective successors and permitted assigns, but will not be assignable or delegable by any Party without the prior written consent of the other Party. Any attempted transfer in contravention of this Section 9.3 shall be null and void.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the sentence 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Party may transfer or assign its rights under this IP Agreement in connection with a merger, acquisition or sale of all or substantially all of its assets, on condition that it provides the other Party with notice of the transfer or assignment', the original clause now directly conflicts with standard business practice. A company involved in a merger/acquisition may not be able to gain consent from the other party, thus voiding the agreement. This could affect either party.
